children.value:
We are all familiar with the phenomenon of ‚Äúwind chill‚Äù ‚Äì we get colder on a chilly, windy day than on a day that is equally cold but has no wind.
Similarly, if you pour sugar crystals into your tea and let them sit on the bottom of your cup, they will take some time to dissolve.
If you stir your tea so that there is flow over the crystals they dissolve almost immediately.
In general, except at microscopic scales, molecular transport mechanisms are usually greatly enhanced by flow.

approach to estimate how fast particles move in fluids, we can use this approach to estimate how molecular transport mechanisms like diffusion are enhanced by particle movement.
The most convenient way to perform this calculation is with another

.
Recall that the Reynolds number is dimensionless, because it is the quotient of a force divided by another force -- the units of force in the numerator and denominator cancel).
The new dimensionless ratio is called the Sherwood number,

children.html: Sh\mathcal{Sh}Sh

Sh=mass¬†flux¬†with¬†diffusion¬†and¬†flowmass¬†flux¬†with¬†diffusion¬†alone\mathcal{Sh} = \frac{\mathit{mass~flux~with~diffusion~and~flow}}{\mathit{mass~flux~with~diffusion~alone}}Sh=mass¬†flux¬†with¬†diffusion¬†alonemass¬†flux¬†with¬†diffusion¬†and¬†flow‚Äã

children.value: For example, suppose we consider a phytoplankton cell that is absorbing nutrients as it slowly sinks in the water column.

children.html: Sh\mathcal{Sh}Sh

children.value:
is the actual mass transport of nutrients into the cell, divided by the mass of nutrients that would be transported if the cell were not sinking but were stationary in the water.
If the cell were stationary, mass transport would occur by diffusion alone.
If the cell is moving, the wind chill and stirred tea examples suggest that nutrient transport might be much higher.
If so, then actual transport is higher than transport by diffusion alone, and

children.html: Sh>1\mathcal{Sh} \gt 1Sh>1
Sh\mathcal{Sh}Sh

children.value: is a function of velocity (in this case, the sinking speed).

children.html: Sh=1\mathcal{Sh} = 1Sh=1

children.value: , for a particle that is moving very slowly or not at all (that is, no enhancement of transport due to movement) to very large values (e.g.

children.html: Sh>100\mathcal{Sh} \gt 100Sh>100

children.value: Because Sh depends on velocity, it is effectively summarized as a function of

children.value: summarizes how fluid flows around the particle.

children.html: Sh\mathcal{Sh}Sh

children.value: is a function of the diffusion rate.
Because diffusion is involved, we need a way to express the diffusion rate of the nutrient (or other solute, as the case may be).
The convenient way to express this is as yet another dimensionless ratio, the

For example, for a spherical particle, the mass transport of solute into the particle due to diffusion alone is
